description: On Saturday morning, Shelbyville citizens gathered in front of the Shelby County Courthouse to demand change. The event, organized by Brittany Andolz, Deja Holly, Hunter Jarman, and Hope Fenton was put on to show the community's support for the Black Lives Matter movement and protest the death of George Floyd.  "We're here to hear our black community speak and let us...
text:
On Saturday morning, Shelbyville citizens gathered in front of the Shelby
County Courthouse to demand change.

The event, organized by Brittany Andolz, Deja Holly, Hunter Jarman, and Hope
Fenton was put on to show the community's support for the Black Lives Matter
movement and protest the death of George Floyd.

"We're here to hear our black community speak and let us know what is really
happening in our community," Andolz said.

The event began with a prayer and was followed by 8 minutes and 46 seconds of
silence. Everyone was silent during the time, including many young children
that were in attendance. After, community members were encouraged to take the
megaphone and voice their thoughts and concerns.

Michael Prolifik Ellis stood up and talked about his family's struggles being
out in the community.

"We can not go to Walmart without someone looking at us crazy," he said. "We
can't eat our food in a diner, without someone looking at us crazy. We can't
jog down the streets without someone looking at us crazy. It's not fair," he
said.

Deja Holly said she was the only black girl in her class at Triton Central
High School her freshman year. She sat by herself, was called racial slurs,
and would have black jokes made to her face.

"They did not like me, they didn't want me there," she said.

Andrea Potter spoke about issues that her 12-year-old daughter, who she
identified as black, has dealt with bullying at school because of her racial
identity.

"I think it's time racists get called out and be uncomfortable," she said.

Wade Lewis, a white man in attendance said he was there to be a part of the
solution.

"It's good to hear people speaking from their hearts," he said. "There's a lot
of pain and frustration, but still a lot of hope."

After the community voiced their thoughts, a march was made around
Shelbyville. Tom DeBaun, mayor, attended that march.

"As the mayor it is important I'm there to hear what is being said and to
represent city government," he said.

He also said he felt it was his duty as a father to bring his family, and have
them be a part of the experience. He feels that in order to make Shelbyville a
place everyone wants to live, all voices need to be heard.

The protest remained civil, and there were a little over 100 people in
attendance.

"If everyone came together this world would be a better place," Ellis said.

title: Black Lives Matter movement supported by Shelbyville
html:
On Saturday morning, Shelbyville citizens gathered in front of the Shelby County Courthouse to demand change.

The event, organized by Brittany Andolz, Deja Holly, Hunter Jarman, and Hope Fenton was put on to show the community's support for the Black Lives Matter movement and protest the death of George Floyd.

"We're here to hear our black community speak and let us know what is really happening in our community," Andolz said.

The event began with a prayer and was followed by 8 minutes and 46 seconds of silence. Everyone was silent during the time, including many young children that were in attendance. After, community members were encouraged to take the megaphone and voice their thoughts and concerns.

Michael Prolifik Ellis stood up and talked about his family's struggles being out in the community.

"We can not go to Walmart without someone looking at us crazy," he said. "We can't eat our food in a diner, without someone looking at us crazy. We can't jog down the streets without someone looking at us crazy. It's not fair," he said.

Deja Holly said she was the only black girl in her class at Triton Central High School her freshman year. She sat by herself, was called racial slurs, and would have black jokes made to her face.

"They did not like me, they didn't want me there," she said.

Andrea Potter spoke about issues that her 12-year-old daughter, who she identified as black, has dealt with bullying at school because of her racial identity.

"I think it's time racists get called out and be uncomfortable," she said.

Wade Lewis, a white man in attendance said he was there to be a part of the solution.

"It's good to hear people speaking from their hearts," he said. "There's a lot of pain and frustration, but still a lot of hope."

After the community voiced their thoughts, a march was made around Shelbyville. Tom DeBaun, mayor, attended that march.

"As the mayor it is important I'm there to hear what is being said and to represent city government," he said.

He also said he felt it was his duty as a father to bring his family, and have them be a part of the experience. He feels that in order to make Shelbyville a place everyone wants to live, all voices need to be heard.

The protest remained civil, and there were a little over 100 people in attendance.

"If everyone came together this world would be a better place," Ellis said.
